children.subject: Thats doable. 61C itself is heavy enough, trust me. If you want to get a good grade in 61C, I will advise you to not take anything else though. It is an important class especially if you are thinking about 161/162 etc.

The CS61C summer website recommends that you don’t take any other classes at the same time. I haven’t taken it yet, so I can’t offer advice from personal experience. You’ll just about constantly have a CS project to work on.

If you plan on doing the readings, I would highly advise against it. 61C has an insane amount of material. It covers not only the highest(warehouse computing, thread-level parallelism, openMP) and lowest level of programming(RISC-V, circuits and registers), but it also teaches you how what cache REALLY is, “intros” you to memory management, and other miscellaneous concepts in CS like input/output, clock cycles, datapaths, networks, energy efficiency for warehouses. 

It’s the last of the 61 series and, in some sense, needs to include all the foundational, core computer science concepts that you would not have otherwise be aware of, outside your interested curriculum, be that in software, hardware, or theory. With that said, 61c fill in many many things and if you really get the most out of it, it’ll excite you for what upper divs will teach you. Many people say they hate it because of how hard it is, but if you think about it, the class is essentially teaching how exactly your computer runs at a middle-level detailed level. You should really pay attention to everything without distractions, which could include R1B, but if the specific R1B subject matter is what’s important, save it for the regular semesters. But if you’re just trying to knock out some requirements, maybe take it at Berkeley Community College for minimal effort so you can spend your time on things you care about(if possible because I don’t think BCC allows out of state students). The grade doesn’t affect your gpa and you get the transfer credit. Hope this helps:)

history.content:
See followups below but if you are allowed to concurrently enroll in 61C at Berkeley and an R1B at a community college, I would say it's doable.

Community college or online R1Bs can have a lower workload than Berkeley's R1A/B and allow you to effectively take R1B P/NP since only the credits transfer, not the letter grade.
Is this doable and do people advise against this? Thank you :)
history.subject: Summer CS61C+R1B
